Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: EVOLUTION OF THE HADROSAURID DENTITION--HISTOLOGICAL AND BIOMECHANICAL INSIGHTS INTO ADVANCED REPTILIAN HERBIVORY
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: EVOLUTION OF THE HADROSAURID DENTITION--HISTOLOGICAL AND BIOMECHANICAL INSIGHTS INTO ADVANCED REPTILIAN HERBIVORY
Gregory M. Erickson and Mark A. Norell
Throughout their 300+ million year history, herbivorous reptiles rarely acquired teeth that allowed for chewing in the manner of ungulate mammals (e.g. horses and cows). The lone exception was the duck-billed dinosaurs (aka hadrosaurids), the dominant herbivores of the Late Cretaceous. In our research we are studying: 1) the steps by which hadrosaur teeth became more complex, 2) how the mechanics of their dentition changed with each step, 3) how such changes allowed for the processing of different food types, and finally 4) how their extensive worldwide radiations were made possible by dental changes. We are specifically documenting the shape and microstructure of the teeth throughout the group, including some of the earliest and latest representatives. From growth lines found in the samples we are determining how long each dinosaur?s teeth took to form, wear down, and be replaced. We are then using these data to create computerized engineering models of the dentitions and using them to explain how the chewing surfaces of each species were created. Ultimately we will correlate these data with dietary information and geographic radiations to gain a comprehensive understanding of how hadrosaurids came to dominant herbivorous roles during the age of dinosaurs. The results will serve as a model for understanding the genesis of complex dental structures and will be of interest to investigators in myriad scientific disciplines (e.g. vertebrate paleontology, paleobiology, evolutionary biology, anthropology, integrative biology, comparative physiology, ecology, herpetology, and mammalogy). Additional benefits of this study include educational opportunities for students and teachers. Justifications and descriptions of the research and findings will be posted on the internet for public access along with an archive of research images. Through the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) Education Department?s summer intern program, high school students have the opportunity for hands-on participation in the project. Teacher training (for high school and middle school teachers) will also be conducted as a result of this grant. Teacher Professional Development Workshops, focusing on dinosaur evolutionary feeding ecology, will be held at the Gottesman Center at the AMNH. In addition this research will be shared with teachers who participate in hands-on histology activities during a special continuing education program at Florida State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal was to provide the first comprehensive, phylogenetically (evolutionarily) controlled analysis of ornithopod (advanced herbivorous dinosaurs) dental histology, biomechanics, and feeding ecology. We coupled new data on dinosaurian relationships with advanced microstructure techniques, and introduced engineering material science experimentation to quantify the patterns of change leading up to and throughout the diversification of hadrosaurids (duck-billed dinosaurs). Our specific objectives were four-fold: 1) Develop a database for investigation of dental form, function, and relationships in ornithopods; 2) Identify and test how various dental tissues contributed to the biomechanics of feeding in these dinosaurs; 3) Document broad-scale patterns of dental structure and biomechanics, and assess their significance for documenting the evolution of ornithopods; and lastly 4) Provide an avenue for interdisciplinary scientific investigation, educational opportunities for students and teachers, and dissemination of findings in both professional and lay-public arenas.

We found that hadrosaurids evolved one of the most advanced dentitions known, with teeth possessing as many as six constituents—more than any mammal. We also found that 70 million year old hadrosaurid teeth remarkably preserve the wear relevant material properties of relative hardness and wear resistance. This made it possible to directly wear the teeth using a reciprocating scratch tester and study how they self-formed to create the complex grinding surfaces (literally the teeth would work today). Our development of a sophisticated three-dimensional wear models revealed how these tissues wore during feeding and came to resemble the dentitions of grazing mammals such as horses and bison. We tested for wear preservation in other dinosaurs and even fossil mammals. Some of the results are quite positive suggesting the study of wear in fossil teeth can see application on a broad scale and lead to better understanding of how modern animal dentitions function and came to be.  The project has led to fruitful long–term collaborations between engineers and paleontologists and stands to revolutionize our understanding of how teeth work in any animal. Notably, the sophisticated wear models we developed are seeing introduction in engineering and stand to facilitate the development of new composite materials for industrial applications.

Numerous students (including minorities and high school students) were involved in the research and advanced their learning skills and made strides toward professional careers in academia and engineering. We have presented our results through publications and presentations in both professional and public venues leading to a more scientifically literate society.
